channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15201] Add hbase-spark to hbase assembly
item.description:
hbase-spark currently is missing from hbase assembly.
We should add it.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: lgtm

-1 overall

This message was automatically generated.

Here is the error in the hbase-assembly build:

[INFO] --- maven-remote-resources-plugin:1.5:process (default) @ hbase-assembly ---

[ERROR] Error invoking method 'get(java.lang.Integer)' in java.util.ArrayList at META-INF/LICENSE.vm[line 1627, column 22]

java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException

	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor26.invoke(Unknown Source)

	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)

	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:606)

The failed command used in the build is:

cd /testptch/hbase/hbase-assembly

mvn -Dmaven.repo.local=/home/jenkins/yetus-m2/hbase-master-1 -DHBasePatchProcess -fae clean install -DskipTests=true -Dmaven.javadoc.skip=true

It was probably due to missing licenses from some the dependencies pulled in by Spark.

But the strange thing is that Spark and its dependencies are 'provided' therefor they are not bundled in the assembly.
I've tested it with top level 'mvn clean package assembly:single -DskipTests'.
It builds fine and it only adds the 'hbase-spark-2.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar' to the assembly.

But my local build with 'cd hbase-assembly' then 'mvn clean install -DskipTests=true' indeed fails with same error as in the Jenkins build.

Sean Busbey
Would you be able to provide some insight?

Jerry He Trying adding debug flags as Samir Ahmic did here https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HBASE-15122?focusedCommentId=15123903&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15123903 Maybe that helps?

Thanks stack.

The LICENSE file generated under hbase-assembly/target shows this before it stops:

No license info included; must update supplemental-models for:



g:oro AND a:oro AND v:2.0.8



Until hbase-resource-bundle/src/main/resources/supplemental-models.xml

is updated, the build should fail.

=====

Check license for included work



<groupId>oro</groupId>

<artifactId>oro</artifactId>

<version>2.0.8</version>



maven central search

g:oro AND a:oro AND v:2.0.8

I checked the dependency tree. It is from the spark-core.
But spark is marked as 'provided' in the hbase-spark pom.

The top level 'mvn dependency:tree' shows:

[INFO] |  +- oro:oro:jar:2.0.8:provided

[INFO] |  +- org.tachyonproject:tachyon-client:jar:0.5.0:provided

[INFO] |  |  \- org.tachyonproject:tachyon:jar:0.5.0:provided

[INFO] |  +- org.spark-project:pyrolite:jar:2.0.1:provided

But running 'mvn dependency:tree' under hbase-assembly shows:

[INFO] |     |  +- oro:oro:jar:2.0.8:compile

[INFO] |     |  +- org.tachyonproject:tachyon-client:jar:0.5.0:compile

[INFO] |     |  |  \- org.tachyonproject:tachyon:jar:0.5.0:compile

[INFO] |     |  +- org.spark-project:pyrolite:jar:2.0.1:compile

where would this put hbase-spark in the assembly? What are we enabling?

If you run 'mvn dependency:tree -Dverbose=true' in hbase-assembly you might be able to see why it promoted things to compile.
HI, Sean Busbey It just adds the hbase-spark-2.0.0-SNAPSHOT-jar to the tarball lib folder.

I dig a little more.
Here is the reason for the QA build problem.
The steps involved in the QA build:

============================================================================

============================================================================

                      Pre-patch master maven install

============================================================================

============================================================================

cd /testptch/hbase

mvn -Dmaven.repo.local=/home/jenkins/yetus-m2/hbase-master-1 -DHBasePatchProcess -fae clean install -DskipTests=true -Dmaven.javadoc.skip=true > /testptch/patchprocess/branch-mvninstall-root.txt 2>&1

Elapsed:   3m 21s

Note that we do a top level mvn install without the patch. The hbase-spark pom is updated in the patch (mark the spark-streaming as 'provided'). But the installed artifact pom is without the change.
Then in the next step:

============================================================================

============================================================================

                            Patch maven install

============================================================================

============================================================================





cd /testptch/hbase/hbase-assembly

mvn -Dmaven.repo.local=/home/jenkins/yetus-m2/hbase-master-1 -DHBasePatchProcess -fae clean install -DskipTests=true -Dmaven.javadoc.skip=true > /testptch/patchprocess/patch-mvninstall-hbase-assembly.txt 2>&1

Elapsed:   0m 18s

cd /testptch/hbase/hbase-spark

mvn -Dmaven.repo.local=/home/jenkins/yetus-m2/hbase-master-1 -DHBasePatchProcess -fae clean install -DskipTests=true -Dmaven.javadoc.skip=true > /testptch/patchprocess/patch-mvninstall-hbase-spark.txt 2>&1

Elapsed:   1m 16s



hbase-assembly in the patch failed.

We went into hbase-assembly directory and did a 'mvn install' in there. But the other pom in the local repo was still the old bad one.
Thus it tried to pull in all the dependencies of spark-streaming, which it should not have done if it had seen the new pom in the local repo.

If it had reversed the order shown in the quoted text (built and installed the hbase-spark module first), we would be good as well.

These new steps of this new QA run are interesting ... Looks like it only goes into the modules touched by the patch to do the mvn install again ...

I have done some local testing to verify the above analysis
Doing a top level build and install without the patch then going into hbase-assembly with the patch causes the problem.

In a real build we should be fine.
+1 from me Jerry He but suggest waiting on the blessing from mighty Sean Busbey; it'll make you feel good.

The build error for module ordering is YETUS-280. you can build with this change in place if you go to the precommit job and use "build with parameters" to check the USE_YETUS_PRERELEASE option.

Does placing it in the lib/ folder cause it to get included in various service classpaths?

-1 overall

Hi, Sean Busbey

The USE_YETUS_PRERELEASE option does its magic. Thanks for the pointer.

Does placing it in the lib/ folder cause it to get included in various service classpaths?

Yes, it'll in the classpath. Is there any concern?
We only have one single assembly and lib, no separate one for client side only. But there is no reference to the jar from the server side.

Yes, it'll in the classpath. Is there any concern?
We only have one single assembly and lib, no separate one for client side only. But there is no reference to the jar from the server side.

Sure, things getting added to the classpath are usually a concern. I don't think we shade anything, so maybe it's not a big deal. Andrew Purtell, Elliott Clark, larsh, Theodore michael Malaska thoughts?

Hi, folks

If there is no more comments or objection, I'd like to get this in.
Will the hbase-spark jar in the hbase lib, there are more choices to manipulate the spark-submit classpath to use the module.

Thanks. Sean Busbey
Pushed to master. Removed the fix version 1.3 since hbase-spark is not in branch-1 yet, but I linked the issue to HBASE-14160 so that we are aware when doing HBASE-14160.

SUCCESS: Integrated in HBase-Trunk_matrix #692 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/HBase-Trunk_matrix/692/)
